title: Blue and white teacups with qilin motif
content:
accession_no_csv: 2017-00275-001 and 002

  Image: 

  object_work_type: porcelain (visual works) teacups Ceramics (object genre)

  title_text: Blue and white teacups with qilin motif

  preference: main

  inscriptions:

  shape: circular

  materials_name: clay blue-and-white (ceramic glaze) ceramic glaze cobalt blue (pigment) porcelain (material)

  techniques_name: freehand drawing (technique) firing (technique) underglazing porcelain painting (image-making) molding (forming) glazing (coating process) throwing (pottery techniques)

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: This is a pair of blue white tea cups painted with the mythological beast
 qilin. Though painted with simple clean strokes with a fine brush
 its features such as the bushy tail and hooves are distinctively visible.  The cobalt blue ink wash however
 spills out of the figure\u0027s outlines. The potting is thin; testament to its refined quality. Encrustation can be found at the base of 001.

  subject_terms_1: porcelain paintings (visual works) qilin legendary beings freehand drawings (drawings) symbolism

  subject_terms_2: Porcelain
 Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties
 1368-1912 Qilin China painting Mythical beasts Blue and white ware China

  subject_terms_3: visual arts Ceramics Decorative arts

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: This delicately-potted pair of teacups are painted with mythical creatures that appear to be the qilin. The imaginary beast
 which was thought to possess the physical attributes of various animals
 was highly popular in Chinese art and culture. Although the qilin on this pair of teacups are rather sketchily painted
 some of these features can still be discerned
 such as the hooves and bushy tail. The qilin was very auspicious as it is believed to embody attributes such as benevolence
 longevity and the bearing of illustrious offspring.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a pair of blue white tea cups painted with the mythological beast, qilin. Though painted with simple clean strokes with a fine brush, its features such as the bushy tail and hooves are distinctively visible.  The cobalt blue ink wash however, spills out of the figure's outlines. The potting is thin; testament to its refined quality. Encrustation can be found at the base of 001.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This delicately-potted pair of teacups are painted with mythical creatures that appear to be the qilin. The imaginary beast, which was thought to possess the physical attributes of various animals, was highly popular in Chinese art and culture. Although the qilin on this pair of teacups are rather sketchily painted, some of these features can still be discerned, such as the hooves and bushy tail. The qilin was very auspicious as it is believed to embody attributes such as benevolence, longevity and the bearing of illustrious offspring.
